Cutting Diet:

Maintenance:

Hungry as duck edition:

>Who is /fat/ for?
For fatties who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Previous Thread >>69673085

>>69694603
Keto's fine. It has side effects (flu, gout, breath, appetite works differently for different people, refeeding is a bitch, slightly higher all-cause mortality) and benefits (flatter blood glucose and insulin, quicker weight loss, some people get lower cravings). If I had diabetes I'd be on it.

The important part is changing your diet and sticking to it, and most diets (keto, med, PSMF if you take vitamins, chicken titty and vegetables, IF, just removing all the pizza+donuts+soda) are reasonable, particularly if you calorie count. We're all trying to do much the same thing. When some autist starts screeching about how his diet is better, it doesn't help.

posts.com: Modern cynicism is passive. It is lifeless. Cynicism says No to the courageous Yes which life demands. It is folded in on itself; crumpled and small. It is arrogant and lazy. It “asks questions” as a means of avoiding the responsibility of an answer, and then asserts what it thinks it already knows—that things are bad. It is a perversion of intelligence, and often seems like intelligence, but it is really just a mask for something much more fundamental: cowardice, denial, metaphysical rebellion. Cynicism is what Peter Sloterdijk called “enlightened false consciousness,” which is “reflexively buffered” against all criticism of itself. It is a circle which continually reaffirms its own impotent biases. It posits a stupid world of stupid people—but the cynic himself is the most stupid of all. If the cynic is not stupid intellectually, he is stupid in a much more fundamental sense. He is Bingus’d out—with a sour heart bathed in cynickery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69680899
>What rack deep?
imo, doesn't matter too much. I got 43" because I had the space for it
>Safeties, strap or flip down?
I like straps because you can micro adjust by altering height placement from front to back. they are the best for bench. when I'm in position, the bar hits my chest, but as soon as I collapse my arch, the straps catch the bar. If I had pin/pipe or flips, the safeties would be too high to get full ROM or be too low to be useful
If I had an extra $200 to burn, I'd have both and use straps exclusively for bench movements and flips for everything else. avoid pin/pipes though

posts.com:
lot of wrong info here. let this brown-haired anon educate you.

taking care of your hair is simple. when you shower, only use cold water when washing your hair. you should use conditioner every day. gently apply it to the ends of your hair.

you should shampoo at most 1-2 times a week. gently apply it to your scalp. definitely never use shampoo if you used it yesterday. shampoo removes all natural oils from your scalp, so when you use shampoo your scalp has to go into overdrive to replenish these oils. this makes your hair greasy. when you shampoo once a week, it brings a good balance where your scalp can maintain its natural oils and your scalp is healthier. NEVER use 2-in-1 or 3-in-1 products, also any shampoos that have sulfates (these are goysoaps that are meant to make you gentiles go bald). read the ingredients and make sure everything is natural.

let your hair air dry as much as possible. don’t use a towel unless it’s microfiber. if you have long hair, you can blow dry, but only use warm or cold air. do it gently or your hair will frizz.

eat stuff that is good for your hair. look up products that boost keratin. eggs and fish are a good start.

>>69660518
>How do you guys take care of your long hair?
Honestly, genetics, mostly.

But, in addition to what a lot of other anons have mentioned (don't wash your hair too often), I also avoid doing anything to damage my hair, which includes hot air blow drying (I most often don't blow dry at all), not brushing when wet, no chemical treatments of any kind (straighteners; although my hair is naturally straight, bleaching/coloring; but then again I'm a dude so it's not like that's a common thing for us anyway). I also cut down on breakage when washing by brushing my hair BEFORE I get in the shower, then scrubbing in the direction of the grain, not some chaotic pattern that will jumble my hair. Yes, it takes a lot longer to get it clean that way but there's way less hair loss that way.

>>69670508
As long as you don't start talking about how your mom took you to the doctor to get weighed but you don't like getting wet, you're probably as smart as the majority of /fit/. I do agree porn plays a big roll, however this goes beyond my natural libido. It’s not just porn and fapping but it’s equally disgusting. I’m addicted to quick instant gratification dopamine rushes. Caffeine, nicotine, food, fapping, porn, weed, etc.
It is disgusting. It’s not so much the urge to cum as it is boredom and the above.


For instance, I was once capable of reading an entire book in a day. No stopping except to use the bathroom or eat, cover to cover. Now I can read maybe 4 pages before I’m distracted or bored. Even if I enjoy what the book is about.


The same goes for video games it’s gotten so bad. I used to have to limit myself, now I get bored immediately and they feel like chores. Obviously vidya is typically an instant gratification dopamine release, but I’ve gotten so bad that’s not even something I can maintain my focus or attention on.


I’ve been urgently trying to fix all of this, cleaning up my diet, getting back into working out, weaning off caffeine and quitting weed with plans fo quit nicotine after those are done. And what can only be called excessive fapping has to go as well. It definitely makes a difference. I would say porn is a bigger problem for sure, but fapping to the point I haven’t busted a full sized load in years is hardly a small problem that wouldn’t be adding to my issues.
It technically is in my head, but it’s not imaginary. Porn and fapping fucks with neurotransmitters. The dopamine and thereafter prolactin cause havoc and lead to the motivation, fatigue, and anxiety compilations I’ve been facing. posts.name: Plutez
posts.com:
>>69692387
Watch through Shane Jerman's log press series. If you apply even 20% of what he says you'll be a lot better off
Part 1 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ekbOK9aX2Rg
Part 2 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5FrwtcdZZpw
Part 3 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ipIt5aD564
>elbows too high and no upperback tension
You want scapula elevation and retraction, rowing the log in. Don't need to think about your elbow position, they will sit where they need to.
You're initiating the clean by flicking your head and back up but the log stays put until you pull it up with your arms and basically jump with it. You want the log stuck to your torso and initating the clean with your hips throwing them up and forward under the log like you're trying to squat it up.
>im lacking in leg drive though
It's explained in the video but you probably want your stance a bit closer, knees tracking outwards instead of forwards, hips stay stacked under the shoulders. You need to be more aggressive/faster with the drive and get up higher onto your toes with. You rotated your arms outwards in the rack and when you dipped the log rolled forward. You might want to keep the elbows forward more for stability.
>circus dumbbell
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EHUsC5JOWes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69679438
It depends on your overall fitness. What causes food to be stored is insulin. I lost a lot of weight through calorie counting when I was 18. It literally worked based on my total daily energy expenditure what I ate and then the deficit pretty much mapped up with the number of calories and the 3500 for a pound of fat. Much later in life I had like many people put the weight back on. I tried doing the exact same thing and it did not work at all. I had my fasting insulin level tested and it was higher than many people have even after they've eaten. So what I found was that fasting didn't work as quickly in the beginning but after a prolonged period of fasting the fasting insulin came down and I was able to lose weight basically in line with the calories in calories out. Also if you have fat in your liver or pancreas and either prediabetes or diabetes, fasting is much more efficient at taking that fat out than just eating a typical diet but fewer calories. There's numerous studies where people on fasting diets versus calorie counting diets have the same calorie deficit but the people who are fasting have lower fasting insulin on things like that. It depends what your goals are. Like if you're healthy what Arnold Schwarzenegger recommends in his book is basically you eliminate carbohydrate until you're just out of ketosis you don't want to be in ketosis but you don't want to eat more carbohydrate than normal. That's from his Encyclopedia of bodybuilding. But that's for a healthy person not a fatty.

Yes you can. I recommend doing it like this:

Monday: Eat, gym.
Tuesday: 24 hours in, cardio.
Wednesday:Eat, Gym.
Thursday: 24 hours in, cardio.
Friday: Eat, gym.

Repeat. That way you do cardio when you are at your weakest and optimize gains/fat burning.

In other news: Been off the fasting for a month now. Got really really tired of rolling for weeks at a time and not making progress in the gym/low energy. Tomorrow will be the day I skip my first OMAD-meal, that way I get a minimum of a 48 hour fast, after that point it usually is quite easy to keep going.

irrelevant, people are different and will stall out at vastly different weight. Beginner, intermediate and advanced refers to your rate and mode of progression, not how much you lift.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
less compound exercises, more isolation exercises

If you have the ability to attach the bands for any angle, then there is no exercise that is best for them, but generally speaking, in a normal environment with normal anchor points, compounds are going to be the worst for bands. You'll reach a point in the strength curve of the movement where it just feels awkward because the band is pulling in a slightly off direction vs using weights that just pull down.

Bands are the best for exercising the smaller muscles of your body and building stability. Think like upper back, arms, and deep hip stabilizers.

I got a free trip to Orlando, and figured I'd check out Disney World while I was there. I like roller coasters, and wanted to check out the set design of the rides.

I was expecting fat people, don't get me wrong, but I was totally unprepared for the prevalence of such obesity. Yeah, there's obese people in the urban northeast, but nothing like what I saw scootin' around Disney. Gosh, these people were huge. Just enormous. And so young. I just can't imagine letting oneself get to that point. As a pretty thin person I really stuck out; I noticed a lot of men looking at me, way more than would at home. I can only attribute this to being one of the only thin youngish women on the property.

A corresponding factor I noticed -- which I never notice in my day-to-day life -- was the prevalence of very high calorie, sugary coffee drinks. Everyone was walking around with Frappucino type things, these monstrous 1,000 calorie sugar bombs with whipped cream on top. I mean honestly so gross to imagine eating that, but god does American obesity make sense now after seeing how prevalent and how damn popular those drinks are.

Finally, I will note that I was on the lookout for Disney adults, and was kind of shocked by what I saw. "Disney Adults" are almost all obese and seemingly low IQ. I know that sounds judgemental and mean, believe me, but eavesdropping on their conversations in line, or just watching how they interact with each other or with their kids. Wow. No wonder they like kid stuff and capeshit. Not too much going on upstairs.

You can roast me all you want for going to Disney, but I will say the roller coasters were super fun, it was an almost free trip, and it was nice leaving the northeast for a couple of days of 70 degree sunshine.

Very depressing to see the state of Americans though.

>>69685161
>Why the sharp drop in France since 2015?
Basically this : >>69693944
>Sugar tax and reformed product packaging laws with simple to follow nutrition score.
and checked.

The European Union passes laws that then European nations have to implement.
So France implemented a better packaging information law, with detailed info of what's inside (Fat, Protein, Salt, Sugar ...), and a easy to use Nutritional Score ("Nutri-Score") from A to F as a quick way to judge the quality / healthiness of different food items.
Also a tax on sugary products.

Then again it's not perfect.
It's still based on the old food pyramid / old scientific consensus from 20 years ago.
Like for example Saurated Fats are still demonized when they shouldn't be, they are not bad for you but they do make you fat if you eat too much and it also doesn't take into account the fact that processed foods are bad in general, compared to unprocessed foods.
Also doesn't take into account the health risks of unsaturated fats and trans-fats/partially-hydroginated-fats.

But the side-effect of demonizing saturated fats is that people eat less fatty foods, and therefore get fat less often.

There's also a ressurgence of the Fitness lifestyle. Younger generations, millenials and zoomers are more into physical fitness, sports, martial arts and so on.
The Instagram/TikTok culture is mostly cancer and appearences, but for young men, it has the positive effect of pushing them towards fitness culture more and more.
If they hang out outside of the far left side of the Internet, they see most influencers and content creators taking care of themselves and going to the gym, especially right-wing people.
Some leftist do fitness too, but since fitness is a right wing dog-whistle, it's a way to fight against leftism and signal to others that you're not a weak commie faggot cuck.

>Are you gonna expect us to believe that we should only do one set?
You can believe whatever you want to believe, but belief is not needed since we already have a robust body of science to back the claim. The only thing you need to understand about that single set though is that it must be excruciatingly difficult and it must be continuous up to the point that you reach momentary muscle failure, whether that be technical failure, absolute failure, positive failure, or you can even go as far as positive, negative, and static failure all at once. So long as you get within 2-3 reps in reserve on a set you have essentially extracted all value that you can from the exercise, but the issue there lies within knowing how close you are to failure, which is impossible to know unless you actually go to failure. By reaching failure, by definition, there is nothing more that you can do. There is nothing left to gain by exercising more, you wouldn't be able to do more anyway

Here's a demonstration of how this is effective
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o7pH_V0NOtI

If youve ever done a set like this then you'll know just how hard it is 60-90 seconds of time under tension until failure with perfect form is optimal and very difficult. When you finish one of those sets, your muscles are fucking FRIED and you simply won't be able to perform another one. You will lose a ton of strength. Depending on how hard you go, you may immediately lose 20% strength or even more than 50% strength. If you drop the weight and keep going you might not even be able to activate your muscles if you keep going to the point of using body weight. If you're newer, you might not be able to move your muscles at all afterward. All the 'multiple set' thing is, is one set with arbitrary breaks thrown in the middle of it. It's unnecessary and is a gimmick created by greedy cunts that has no bearing in reality. You can do em if you want, but it's not necessary. It's just more time efficient and clear

>>69683332
>you're not close to failure for a lot of those 60 seconds
As long as you reach failure then that is all that matters. The point of the slow speed is to promote safety by reducing peak forces that you subject your joints and connective tissues to when you move weight. This ensures longevity and an injury free fitness progression. This also allows you to SLOWLY approach failure with a lower weight. By reaching failure with a lower weight you can be sure that you're that much closer to stimulating all fibers. The penultimate of stimulation is to go until you cannot move your own body weight anymore.

>This is a bit of a complex topic with a lot of things to understand when it comes to anatomy, but I'll try to keep it as brief as possible
You can only exercise fibers in a muscle group if there is a strength demand placed upon them.
>All fibers are recruited sequentially from the smallest to the largest.
A fiber will always produce the strongest contractile force it can muster
>Fibers will grow if they receive a growth stimulus by way of fatiguing them
Once fibers can no longer produce force, they have been fatigued and stimulated
>Fibers are fatigued sequentially from smallest to largest
Not going to failure means that the largest fibers will not have received stimulus
>By going to failure, one can ensure with no doubt in their mind that they have 100% effectively stimulated and fatigued all muscle fibers taking part in a particular exercise
By ensuring that 100% of your muscle fibers have been fatigued, you can ensure the maximum amount of growth stimulus possible from a single exercise

The goal is to hit failure, not to get a certain time under tension. Even though it's not all high effort to the same degree, if you take the exercise to a point where your muscle barely works anymore, you're getting the same result regardless of weight, sets, or reps (kinda) Anything within 5-35 reps produce the same gains. over and under doesn't work as well

>>69683587
Injury prevention is #1. There's next to 0% chance that you'll ever harm yourself doing 5-10 second reps with a weight you will tap out in 60-90 seconds with, which is usually around 30%-50% 1rm. Slowly approaching failure also increases your capability to exercise the muscle to a greater degree. Moving slowly allows for you to produce more muscular contractile force (not the same as force applied to joints). By moving more slowly you allow the actin and myosin filaments more time to grip onto each other and ensure that the maximum amount of filaments are being utilized. If you go really hard really fast only a few of them will grab each other, propelling you in the motion quickly, at which point momentum takes over somewhat, reducing the work done by your muscles mid rep. Doing it slower gets more actin and myosin cross-bridging over a much greater range of motion, which theoretically could prevent cases of drastic regional hypertrophy though that specific claim has not been studied yet. It's likely that it would if it were directly compared to faster rep speeds.

>>69683671
Not quite sure. That's just what the studies have shown. Maybe the subjects never actually reached the point of muscular failure in those studies and just gave up once it got too difficult. They might have just gotten tired, utilizing all of their stored ATP. If the weight is waaay too light then it is possible that they are not stressing the muscle enough to demand greater muscle recruitment. If you're doing such light weight it's possible that the slow twitch muscles are going through a cycle. They are recruited then they are fatigued. They then rest for a short period. After they have recovered (slow twitch fibers recover extremely quickly) they are put back into the rotation of recruitment. As they are performing work, other slow twitch fibers are resting. Then those burn out. The other fibers that have already recovered then are fresh again and return to work. You could Theoretically have such strong and developed muscle fibers that the slow twitch ones just continue to cycle like this without having to recruit fast twitch fibers, especially if the weight is particularly low, which appears to occur around the 35 rep mark. You would still get gains from this, but the gains would only be limited to the slow twitch fibers, which are the fibers that are least susceptible to increases in size and strength.

>>69683830
Tons of people report the same thing with the HIT approach, which is what it seems that you're doing now. If you do them slowly and with 0 momentum you'll notice that your joints will feel even better. The next step in growing greater muscle and protecting yourself in the long run is to analyze your frequency. For naturals, there appears to be an upward limit in protein synthesis capability, though the limit is unknown. Most people will exercise several times a week thinking that if they don't exercise all the time then they will lose their gains, but it takes 3 weeks (21 days) of inactivity in order to BEGIN to lose muscle unless you are literally bed-ridden or a limb is immobilized. One study, seemingly the first of its kind, also showed that in untrained subjects, they were continuing to see increases in muscle size and strength for up to 20 days after a single bout of exercise. The MAXIMUM that a natural should be exercising is twice per week but many people could still benefit to a comparable degree from exercising only once per week or even less. Taking 10 days off also resensitizes your body to the activation of P70S6K, which plays a direct role in myofibrillar muscle protein synthesis. Taking 10 days off every 6 weeks will resensitize you. So if you're having issues with your joints you could always do sessions less often and see the exact same gains or even better depending on where you are in your fitness progression. The bigger you become, the more absolute damage you can do to your muscles and therefore the more time you need to rest. As your ability to do damage can increase by 300%+, your ability to recover only improves slightly (around 50% bonus protein synthesis from untrained to elite), thus necessitating that the more advanced you are the more rest you need and not the other way around, which is generally what bro scientists would recommend. I made an infographic to show this. I hope it is as clear as I think it is. Feedback appreciated

>>69684062
Cardio failure is when your ability to send oxygen to cells and remove metabolic waste products is outstripped by the output or creation of them. If you're feeling intense burn, are getting extremely winded, are getting tired after each rep yet are continually able to keep repping, etc. then you are approaching cardio failure. It's a sort of false-failure, as your muscles are still capable of producing substantial force given a short rest. If you're experiencing Cardio failure then you should increase the weight so that you reach muscular failure first or utilize rest-pause to continue to rep if you're close enough to muscle failure that you can reach it within a few more reps. You'll know when you're reaching or are at cardio failure, as you'll feel like you just ran a marathon and are breathing so hard that you can't talk at all.

Cardio failure may occur at first when you start exercising, as your capillaries and mitochondria have not yet developed significantly to keep up with the demand. You will then enter into a progression period where you will not experience it for a long time. After you get significantly large it will start to creep in again (Like once you're advanced bodybuilder status). At that point there's nothing much you can do to stop it as your cardiovascular demands in order to simply meet muscle failure even with a very high weight are very high. At that point you'll need to use various techniques to hit true failure such as rest-pause and drop sets.

posts.com:
>>69685357
Actual muscle damage at the cellular level. If you look deeper into that link, there is a section that covers muscle damage. Soreness, swelling, and pain is a good indicator of muscle damage, as well as the amount of strength lost immediately following exercise. These are the two major indicators that you can rely on unless you have access to a medical facility that can check you for creatine kinase activity, c-reactive protein (the marker for inflammation), and a few other ones that I forget. If you have lost more than 50% of your strength, you are not even fully recovered until AT LEAST 7 days after you performed the exercise. If you lost around 20% of your strength and are experiencing DOMS for around 2 days, then you are not fully recovered until around 4-5 days following an exercise. This doesn't mean that you can't make gains if you're sore, but generally that means that you shouldn't be exercising at that time, despite what other people on the internet would tell you.

Luckily, the more that you regularly expose your muscles to damage, the more resilient they become. The best way to build muscle resilience is to go to absolute negative failure. Eccentric/negative training disproportionately causes the most muscle damage compared to any other kind of training when you first implement it and studies have shown that after 3 sessions of eccentric training that the amount of damage that you experience is almost 0. By doing regular concentric training though, you'll experience next to 0 muscle damage after around 10 weeks of consistent training, such that most of your bodily resources can be allocated to new myofibrillar muscle protein synthesis rather than repair.

Joint and tendon pain should never be a part of resistance training ever at any point. You exercise to get stronger, not to produce an injury, which ultimately is the only thing that can happen as you add more reps, sets, weight, peak forces, etc.

There are only a few things your core actually does. Your abs perform spinal flexion, so a sit up or a crunch to failure will work. Obliques perform twisting of your trunk and straightening of your trunk when you're bent sideways. Do an exercise that involves twisting such as this https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pAplQXk3dkU . Do an oblique exercise that also trains bending. The best bending exercise is a side bend. The lower abs as well as the psoas work to pull your legs upward to your chest, so you can do hanging leg raises to work both lower abs and psoas. 4 exercises that will cover everything.

crunch
oblique twist
side bends
Leg/Knee raise

The muscles of the core also have a massive static strength role in every day life. Force transfer from the lower body to upper body only happens if the torso does not disipate the energy laterally. For this reason, the core muscles can benefit from deadlifts, squats, and pallof presses. The muscles do not move under load but the moment arm on them is dynamic. When you run or do a pull up you isometrically contract your core muscles to maintain a rigid body and vertically transfer force.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69688110
No. Cardiovascular adaptation is something that occurs on the cellular level as well as systemically. The localized cardiovascular adaptations are maximized upon reaching that burning sensation or upon failure. If you've hit that, then you're building up as many metabolic waste products as your body can handle or produce at that time, which provides the stimulus needed in order to force an adaptation. Continuing past this point is simply willful masochism. Having more waste products than you can alleviate is all you need to do. By maximizing waste product buildup, you trigger growth of new capillaries at the target site as well as signal adaptation to the mitochondria at the cellular level. Aerobic and anaerobic differentiation don't exist on a practical level. They are real mechanisms, but at the point that you're maxing out your anaerobic potential, which always comes first in any exercise that you do, the aerobic system is being maxed out too.

For the overall systemic affect, you don't actually need to reach cardio failure to get the systemic benefits of having done cardio exercise, as this is provided by shearing forces on the capillaries and heart. As you are contracting intensely, your muscles squeeze your veins and pump blood to the heart in an extremely efficient manner. This is called the venous return mechanism. As there is a massive increase in blood flow back to the heart and capillaries through this mechanism, they are subject to extreme shear forces, which is what provides the stimulus to provide stronger cell walls to the veins themselves. The massive influx of blood also stretches the heart, as it is engorged with high volumes of blood. This stretching strengthens the heart by the same shearing forces.

I can go a little more into detail with a few things. There is more to how this works. Someone can get fantastic overall cardio by only lifting weights, but if they want to be a marathon runner then that's a different story.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69688263
To add to this, in addition to the cellular adaptations that happen at the level of the mitochondria and the systemic benefits, there are also activity specific skill and cardio benefits. For some reason, when the human body does something over and over again, they become WAY more efficient at doing that one particular thing. You can maximize your cellular and systemic benefits to the moon, but if you want to become a great runner for example, then you need to run. This is extremely specific for some reason though. A guy that chops logs all day won't carry over the specific beneficial cardio adaptations to fighting for example. Why this occurs? I don't think we have an answer for that just yet, all we know is that it happens. So if you want to become elite at your sport or activity, you need to perform that sport or activity to the most intense degree you can and do it often. Also, skill itself does not transfer between activities. Learned skill is exact and precise. If you get really good at swinging a weighted bat, this skill won't benefit you if you swing a standard bat. In fact, in many cases it will have a negative skill transfer, actively making you worse.

Should you? No. Can you do it and still make progress? Yes. Would you make less progress if you trained anyway instead of just resting? Extremely likely. If you want to continue to exercise and worry that your grip is a limiting factor, significantly reduce the weight, go very slowly, and rep until your target muscle gives out. You don't need a lot of weight to get a great workout. Most people could cut the amount of weight they do normally by over half and get the same or better stimulus by just approaching failure slowly over 60-90 seconds.

>>69689889
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o7pH_V0NOtI&t=1s

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n0u7tgOaxcQ
>(Don't mind the dyel scientists, they have dogshit genetics)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r9x8eDyp5cM

Do a single set of any given exercise just like in those three videos. You can also take the exercises beyond positive failure and also do eccentrics to negative failure. Do that once or twice per week maximum for a given muscle group. Dial in your diet. Make sure to get plenty of sleep. Do 6 weeks on, 10 days off, 6 weeks on, 10 days off. If you're not making gains, add more rest days. At the point in which you need 10+ days between the same muscle group in order to see gains between exercises, you don't need to cycle 6 weeks on and 10 days off anymore. You can start by doing full body all on one day and then break it up into a split once you can't complete the entire workout anymore.

You'll get either the same or far better results than doing high volume work. You won't fuck yourself up either. You'll also spend a tiny fraction of the time in the gym compared to everyone else. Just keep in mind though, this will only work if you take the set to your absolute limit and literally go until your muscle gives out, which many people either have never done or would not be willing to do. If you can't or won't do that, then volume training would likely be better as it is easier in terms of absolute momentary exertion even though you will need to spend more time exercising. 5-7 shitty sets is roughly equivalent to 1 properly performed set.

I learned that over training is a myth the hard way.
You actually have under adaption.
How do I know this?
I use to work a job stacking, sorting and re-organizing golf cart batteries.

12 volt golf cart batteries weigh close to 95 pounds when filled with distilled water.

I did this 5 days a week, 8 hours a day, 40 hours a week.

We moved them with straps, by hand.

The first month on this job I would come home and eat thousands of calories and fall asleep until the next morning.
My weekends were spent stretching, paying for massages and buying/testing acupressure, heat pads, epsom salts, etc…
Basically I was sore, tense, hungry and sleepy AF 24/7.

But I adapted a little more every month, until eventually moving around 30 to 95 pound batteries for 8 hours a day, 5 days a week just felt normal.

Now I’m a fully trained golf cart mechanic and don’t have to do that bitch work anymore.

The weird thing is, when I had that job I got extremely strong and a had a ton of endless stamina but my muscles didn’t really grow much.

They got a little bigger but looking back, you would of thought they would of grown a lot.

>>69691293
That's the benefit of the repeated bout effect. Overtraining refers to the potential to get bigger and stronger through myofibrillar muscle protein synthesis and overtraining means to inhibit that specific process. The repeated bout effect refers to many other physiological adaptations that occur in response to doing the exact same thing over and over again. People can become incredibly efficient at doing specific things if they do them long enough. The most stark example of this ever discovered was when the Hadza tribe of Africa was analyzed. They do more physical activity in a day than most Westerners do in a week, so you would expect them to burn several times more calories based on their activity level, but in actuality, they burned the exact amount of calories that you would expect them to burn based on a simple calculation of their stats such as age, height, weight, etc. This phenomenon is not currently known how it works, but it is theorized that if you perform the exact same thing over and over that the body will deprioritize other bodily process in order to send more resources to the most needed cells. The mitochondria also can become several times more efficient if they are worked continually to a seemingly damned impossible degree. It could be that your mitochondria were drastically increased in their efficiency and thus you were able to carry batteries all day despite having similar size and strength muscles. With how specific the repeated bout effect appears to be, it is unclear to what degree this transfers to other non-trained activities.

>>69680260
Psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioner. Nurse practitioners (NP) can do most of the things a physician can do but in a more limited scope. They can diagnose and treat diseases/prescribe drugs, but they require varying levels of oversight depending on the state. They also don't do surgery. A PMHNP is an NP who specializes in psychiatry and mental health. As for why they exist, there just aren't enough physicians to keep up with demand, so NPs of various specializations can step in and take routine cases. They help keep costs down sometimes too.

You're seeing exactly the same thing that I'm seeing but you're choosing to perceive it as a moral issue instead of a medical one. But we know for a fact that the frame you're choosing doesn't make anything better. If someone's failings are moral then all you can do is preach to them, and we know that doesn't change behaviour.

Think about logically. You think that your sister had a choice between being a productive and successful person or a useless waste of space. But who would ever choose the second option? Nobody. Doesn't that sort of reveal to you that maybe it wasn't a choice?

I'm the last person to defend malingerers. I fucking despise malingering in all of its forms. But when I hate things, I research them. Malingering - genuine malingering - is pretty rare. Usually what you get is people who are pretending to malinger because that's less embarrassing than admitting that they genuinely tried and failed. If I really want to bench 100kg and I really try hard to do it, and I fail - that sucks. But if I pretend that I never cared about it in the first place? That's why you get unemployed people who say that actually they don't even want a job. That's easier to say than that they applied to 40 places and got rejected by every single one, that they're so useless and fucked up that they literally can't even get paid labour digging ditches.

Not all malingering is like this. There is genuine malingering, of course. But open your mind to the possibility that character failings are actually a relatively rare cause of failure. And that's a good thing. Because if the reason your sister was a fuck up was because of circumstance or experience - we can fix that. If it's because she was just a bad person, that's much harder to fix. It's GOOD that people aren't bad. It means there's hope that they can be made better than they are.

>>69679125
myo reps is supposed to cover all the sets and reps for an exercise. usually, its an isolation or maybe machine exercise because the metabolic fatigue will fuck up your form on compounds.

so you do a higher rep activation set and then smaller cluster sets to add volume. this is based on the theory that only the final few reps of a higher rep set create useful fatigue/stress. the early reps are redundant, "junk volume" that you just pass on the way to those fatiguing reps at the end.

>why are you comparing chest muscles to leg muscles.
They're both muscles? How about a better comparison; triceps and quads since they both work to extend their respective hinge joints. When you do overhead extensions or any other tricep movement you always go down until your forearm squishes against your bicep (aka full ROM) before extending. Same with the quads. The quads don't magically turn off the moment you go below parallel; if anything they are much more active due to the greater stretch. There is no reason why you should arbitrarily cut the ROM short just so you can lift more weight unless you're training for strength instead of hypertrophy.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69688014
A superset is an exercise pair (eg curls + pushdowns)
A giant set is 3 or more exercises paired (eg curls + pushdowns + lateral raises + weighted sit-ups)

posts.name: Anonymous

Also forgot to mention that while you typically rest a bit on supersets, on giant sets you typically don't rest at all since by the time you finish the last exercise the muscles involved in the first one have already recovered so you can just endlessly loop through the exercises until all the sets are done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69689414
>Imo trap bar deadlift is better because there is less lower back stress and it is still enough of a hinge to produce posterior chain stimulus. Combined with BSS it works the whole leg well.
True but I still think that RDLs make more sense because at least for myself personally I don't feel my hamstrings at all on conventional deadlifts let alone trap bar deadlifts. I prefer to have each leg day contain 1 quad dominant squat and 1 hamstring dominant hinge as the two pillars of the day with everything else filling in the gaps. Plus although you're much more bent over on RDLs (esp with deficit and/or wide grip) the absolute load is much less so the lower back stress isn't super high. And personally I don't use BSS as my main squat because if I did I would need to do like 6-7 sets on both days to get enough quad stimulus which would be nightmarish; instead I do 4 sets of pause ATG high-bar squats on both days and 3 sets of either BSS or ATG split squats later in the session.

Also I do hip thrusts but they're all the way at the end of the session, reason being is that despite the fact that my ass is already big my hamstrings are so strong that my glutes are actually lagging by comparison, so I need to do direct work so that the discrepancy doesn't become worse lol. Also they're not particularly taxing so I don't see why they should be a main movement when you can still do them when you're tired

If you're talking front splits, RDLs and ATG split squats are great. RDLs should be progressed to a large deficit (bar to toes is ideal) with a wide grip, and ATG split squats to flat ground with a good bit of weight (50% bw bar on back isn't too bad). From those alone I'm almost able to do the front splits, and in a month or two I'll probably have it (added some static stretching to get it a bit faster tho)

For middle splits, you can do weighted tailor's pose for reps for the adductor muscles that don't cross the knee joint. For the gracilis, the only thing I can think of are straight-legged seated good mornings (essentially a regressed seated pancake), besides that you'd just have to train the middle splits itself

>1.5 mile run
>coping about flat feet and shin splints
Navyoid/airforceoid detected

Clowning aside, there's really nothing that can be done to improve your run time significantly between now and then besides just freaking out and refusing to give up. I went from a high 16 to a high 14 minute 2 mile just from the impending source of doom that I was going to qualify. That's all you can really do.

I was once in your exact boat but with the Army instead of Navy/AF. Wicked shin splints, not very fast, the works—I had 4 years of powerlifting with very little running, so my shins and heart were just not up to the task. At one point, I could hardly walk because of how fucked up my shins were.

Anyway, there's a few things that worked for me. I went to a dedicated running store where they filmed my running style in slow motion. They found that I tend towards overpronation when I land, so they recommended a few different shoes to solve the problem. Being as I am a big bastard, I opted for a shoe with more cushioning (specific model is the Hoka Arahi 5). This made the shin splints less debilitating, but they were still there.

I still had shin splints for about a year after this, but there's a few things I did to mitigate them. For me, massaging my soleus before and after running (mostly before) helped a lot, as did stretching my hamstrings before running. To solve the issue entirely, you need more time on feet, as this will make your bones stronger. I HIGHLY recommend getting a heart rate monitor (preferably a chest heart rate monitor) and running no faster than your max aerobic heart rate (180-your age to find it for yourself). Very slowly build up to 90 minutes of running in 2 sessions per week, then add another day in. You'll probably need to walk sometimes. If you're doing 15 miles per week and lifting weights, you will be in good shape in the future. Read "Training for the Uphill Athlete" for further info, but this is what has worked for me so far.

Thinking the way to go is do that stuff with 5 rep sets, then after do other higher rep stuff. But then what exercises/muscles need high reps or low reps? Does one muscle respond better to 10 reps vs 5 or 20? Is this or that exercise better than this other one? Everywhere I look everyone has different answers for everything. Like I have to listen to every different viewpoint from anons or YouTubers and just pick the one that seems best but that seems dumb and I always feel like maybe I'm doing the wrong shit and wasting time. Like what if I get stuck and can't deadlift more? I'm thinking the way out of that is to do another variation that moves more weight like a sumo, since it limits the ROM and certain parts of your body get more used to that higher weight, so that will help you with the conventional later on at a lower weight you couldn't do? I'm rambling and coming up with random shit I think about. Point is idk what the fuck I'm doing and I just listen to stuff and pick what seems to make the most sense.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69667453
The easiest way to learn is to ask good questions. Instead of "How do I get stronger" and getting a bunch of random responses, ask "My deadlift plateaued, what can I do to increase it?" which will lead to a much smaller pool of answers.

You're never going to get a straight answer since lifting has so many variations for so many people, and what works for some doesn't work for others. The best you can do is listen and adapt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
How much intensity is required for hypertrophy in isolation and compound excersizes?
For example if I do bicep curls or incline DB press, are 4x10-12 reps enough, assuming I'm close to failure on every set?
What rep range should I aim for with heavier compounds like bench presses or hack squats? I try going for 8-10 but I fail around 5-6 every time I try increasing the weight.
For example I can bench 1pl8 for 8 times but the moment I add .25 plates (10 kilos), I can barely do 3 or 4. What am I doing wrong?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69667617
it's a myth that only certain rep ranges make hypertrophy possible, just a recommended range of reps to get the most out of it without completely gassing yourself for other lifts. I'd say 2-3 sets of 10-12 is perfect for most isolations. For compounds I'd max it out at 3-4 sets of 6-8.
>I try going for 8-10 but I fail around 5-6 every time I try increasing the weight.
Stick at the lower weight until you can hit the max reps for at-least two sessions in a row. Then increase by 5 lbs for lower body lifts, and 2.5 for upper body.
>I can bench 1pl8 for 8 times but the moment I add .25 plates (10 kilos), I can barely do 3 or 4
Well yeah dude no shit, you're adding over 20 lbs to the bench. Your working weight isn't going to be that much lower than your 1RM. You should be adding about 1-2kg max per session when going up in weight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69670252
Tendons, joints, cartilage, bone, it's all like muscles in that they adapt to stress and strengthen, but the trick is they do so much more slowly. When you're in a position where you can't really build all the tissue that comes with strengthening, all that can become a bit of a problem.
Go lighter. Not too much lighter, but slightly lighter. Try to maintain more than progressing. Accept that progression won't be as fast as you'd like, because you are trying to lose weight. When it's gone, then you can really think about how to strengthen the lot.

Honestly man unless you're seriously overweight I'd stop with the weight loss. You've probably lost a decent amount of weight, right? You'll notice that it's actually not as hard as one would think to lose. Maybe it's hard, but nowhere near as hard as someone would initially think.
Muscle is the opposite. It builds *much* more slowly than fat, but on the flipside the body prefers to not part with existing muscle tissue (and other various tissues) it if it can help it. You're in it for the long term, right? Over the long term, this is a shorter route towards gaining a "goal body".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69675342
Stretching might be not as important as people make it out to be. Depending on your age and fitness/pain.
Stretching increases blood flow to the muscle, just don't stretch too much/too agressive because you will damage some tissue.
If you stretch some muscle that is really tight, you will feel really good and will want to continue working on stretching it.
Having balanced pairs of muscles will do more for you than just working a muscle and stretching it (useless).
If you feel that a short muscle is preventing you from doing a movement or adding too much resistance, you will improve the performance in this excercise, just by stretching the opposing muscle, ie hamstring in jefferson curl.

Need a routine rating boys.
Hit 1/2/3/4 for reps with Nippard's hypertrophy program, and now I'm changing my training to include more functional movements while at least keeping enough strength for 1/2/3/4.

It's a full body routine, I know it'll be long sessions (1h30) but I'm fine with that.
My goal is to keep building strength, enhancing motor control and build bulletproof joints for hiking and rooning:

A :
- Back Squats 3x6
- Barbell OHP 2x8
- DB OHP 2x8
- Single leg deadlift 3x10
- Single arm lat pulldown 3x10
- Cable fly 3x10
- Reverse cable fly 3x10
- Concentration curls 4x12

B:
- Deadlift 3x5
- Close grip DB Bench press press 3x8
- Leg extension 3x10
- Weighted decline crunch 3x10
- Oblique crunch 3x15
- DB Bent Over row 3x10
- Bulgarian split squat 3x12
- Dips 3x8

C:
- Front Squats 3x6
- Pistol squats 2x5
- DB Incline bench press 3x8
- Seated leg curl 3x10
- Hip thrusts 3x10
- EMOM with deadlift/row/high pulls/thrusters for 10 minutes

How's this for a routine? I can only workout at home for now, and all I have are some adjustable dumbbells and resistance bands. I've been lifting for about 6 months and the program I've been using is ok, but I've already had to make changes to it and swap stuff around so it's turned into a bit of a mess, so I wanted to just start from scratch.
I've added abs and forearms every day since I've heard you should hit them frequently, and I've added neck a couple of times throughout the week too.

Day 1
Chest, Shoulders, Triceps

Bench Press 4 x 8-12
Overhead Press 4 x 8-12
Pullovers 4 x 8-12
Lateral Raises 4 x 8-12
Triceps Pushdowns 4 x 8-12
Neck Curls 3 x 10
Crunches 4 x 15
Dumbbell Holds 3 x 15 secs

Day 2
Biceps, Back, Traps

Bicep Curls 4 x 8-12
One Arm Rows 4 x 8-12
Shrugs 4 x 8-12
Hammer Curls 4 x 8-12
Side Bends 4 x 8-12
DB Holds 3 x 25 secs

Day 3
Legs

Squats 4 x 8-12
Calf Raises 4 x 8-12
Deadlift 3 x 8-12
Hip Thrusts 4 x 10
Neck Curls 3 x 10
Crunches 4 x 15
DB Holds 3 x 15 secs

Day 4

Rest

Day 5
Full Upper Body

Bench Press 4 x 8-12
One Arm Rows 4 x 8-12
Triceps Pushdown 4 x 8-12
Bicep Curls 4 x 8-12
Shrugs 4x 8-12
Overhead Press 4 x 8-12
Plank 3 x 30 secs
DB Holds 3 x 15 secs

Day 6&7

Rest

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69685461
I like how you've set it up(PPLxUxx).
>Side Bends 4 x 8-12
>Dumbbell Holds 3 x 15 secs
Don't know what those are but they sound useless.
>Pullovers 4 x 8-1
Move to Pull day and do them deeper and you'll hit both the lats and the upper chest a bit.
All a bent over row/chest supported row/DB row and a pronated wrist curl to the pull day.
>Triceps Pushdown 4 x 8-12
I'm guess you're using resistance bands? If so, try swapping them out for DB skull crushers. Reverse curls on Upper day instead of regular curls.
Overall it's quite good. I don't like DL and squatting on the same day as they will effect each other and only having 1 day with all main leg exercises means you'll miss out. If you set it up like: LPPxUxx, you can move the deadlift to the upper day or add a heavy rack pull instead.

>>69691662
Don't do cardio prior to lifting, wastes energy for no reason. You can warmup just fine without cardio. If you still want to hit it it do it at the end of the session.
>Normally takes 2 and a half hours.
already a sign you're either doing too much or taking too long. The average session should rarely cross over 90 minutes. 4 sets for isolations is a bit overkill and you can get away with 2-3 for similar growth and far less time spent.

And my advice would be to cut out the crunch machine, it's too forgiving on bad form and can let your other muscles compensate for a weak core.

>>69694377
This is not unusual, people are afraid of losing strength and muscle during pauses, and while 3 weeks of illness (depending on how much you ate) can result in some muscle loss, the main effect you'll feel is a loss of coordination, the nervous system "dials back" quicker than actual muscle mass but also recovers far quicker, just get back into the rythm of it and you'll be back to your old strength pretty quickly, at worst a few weeks but usually even quicker than that. You might also still be somewhat affected by the aftereffects of the illness and having to rest for so long, so just take your time and don't stress it

Roasting the bone improves the flavor before making it into broth. It helps break down the structures of the bone so that more of the minerals and marrow flavor can seep into the stewing liquid.
Putting raw bone into liquid is like not salting your food -- it'll still be edible but you're not improving the flavor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69694236
You're not building up layers of browning/maillard reaction if you throw your meat and veggies in the stew uncooked, which is what gives meat that savoury steaky flavour and aroma. Literally just a quick sear on both sides until its browned then add your braising liquid.
A non-spastic way to do it would be
>heat oil of in pot or dutch oven
>sear oxtails / any extra meat until deeply browned on both sides
>remove, add aromatics (onion, celery, capscicum, etc) and sautee
>deglaze if you wanna be fancy but not required
>throw meat and liquid in and spices or whatever and braise until tender
Ultimately you do you but if you're at all interested in learning to cook better then controlling browning is like, the easiest thing you can do towards making your food taste restaurant quality other than pumping your food full of butter MSG and sugar.

Started in October: I was a pussy and didn't want to inject because I heard the cream worked for most patients. Got my shit checked, total test was 250. This was while I was lifting 3x a week, eating decent, and taking a fuck ton of supplements.

So the first two weeks or so was excellent, I felt great and my mind was sharp as a knife. Then once my natural T production fell I felt like crap for the next two months. Tested at 283 total test but my E2 was though the roof. Doc put me on Anastrozole and doubled my dose. This made a minor improvement but after a month we both decided to go the subQ injection route. Two weeks into injections and I feel noticeably better, back to that high I originally had when I started and effectively had twice my normal levels.

So basically don't wait as long as I did giving the cream a try if you even bother going that route. Yes I was putting it on my balls and giving it ten minutes to absorb. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69688923
It's never worth it in my opinion because HCG exists.

I was diagnosed with clinically low testosterone (~250 ng/dl) at age 28. Doesn't seem to have to do with lifestyle; I sleep enough, eat right, I'm not fat, I'm physically active, I don't have any deficiencies etc. It was just that I started feeling worse and worse over a period of multiple years, lack of energy, sleepiness, ED, loss in strength despite working out etc. My wife eventually begged me to finally go to the doctor, thinking that I might have some serious illness. I didn't think it was a testosterone deficiency, because I had had a relatively high T value in my youth (was measured at ~ 800 ng/dL in my early 20s). Turns out I indeed had it.

My doctor recommended me not to take TRT because it sometimes causes testicular atrophy and my wife and I were
trying for a second child back then (surprisingly enough, my sperm count was - and is - okay and I'm fertile despite my T deficiency). So instead, he prescribed me HCG.

That stuff does wonders; I inject 250 iu every two days and my T levels have returned to ~600 ng/dL. Still not very high, but well within normal range and I feel normal again. I have fathered two more children since then, so my fertility is decent as well.

As long as HCG exists, I see little reason to take testosterone at replacement levels. You will achieve pretty much the same result but at the expense of risking testicular atrophy and being permanently dependent on it because you can't produce any testosterone naturally anymore. So why risk that? Taking Testosterone for actual roiding, so to increase your levels beyond a normal range, is a different story of course.

>>69695315
Not that guy you responded to. But I started off doing C25K on a treadmill and transitioned to running outside. It's so much better. Sure, I can't watch TV while doing it. But I can still listen to music or a podcast.

And running outside is just so much fucking better. The elevation is inherently more variable with less even terrain. You also have to deal with headwinds and obstacles. This just helps build up leg strength and resilience.

But, overall, I just fell in love with preparing for -- and pushing through -- the environmental challenges. Going for a run in the rain; in the winter or the snow; in the sweltering summer heat; when it's humid and windy; all take different types of prep. They all challenge you in different ways. And you always feel like you've really overcome something when you complete the run successfully in spite of the weather. My favorite is cold weather runs.

So I guess the TLDR is: running outside is a little more challenging, and a lot more fun/stimulating/engaging.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69693824
It's not horrible but there's a lot of room for improvement
>5x5
Meme shit. Swap to 4x8-12. Low reps aren't that good for building muscle, although you'll get pretty damn strong
>skullcrushers
Do them inclined or RIP your elbows
>biceps and triceps separate
Always superset them. It saves time and they're completely antagonistic to one another so they don't impede the the performance of one another when done back to back
>deadlift, squat, and RDL all on the same day
You must seriously hate your low back. Drop the DL in favor of the RDL. Put the RDL right after the squats and do them for high volume/light weight
>goblet squat
Swap for split squats or lunges
>pullups
Do them assisted if you can't do them normally. Rows alone won't cut it. The upper back needs a fuckton of volume. Add them after the RDL and squat on the lower day to decompress your spine. You can work upper back daily if you bias different muscles each day so the lifts shouldn't interfere with eachother
>dips
Unnecessary if you like bench press more. They work the same muscles in similar ways
>missing elements
Add a rear delt raise and lateral raise. They can be supersetted with just about anything. Versatile and easy to fit in. The rear delts and lateral delts don't grow much without isolation. Calf raises optional but welcome so your leg looks more aesthetic. For both the raises and the calf work always take your sets to failure and well beyond. The delts and calves are workhorse muscles and can take a lot of punishment

Also >>69693925 is a solid powerbuilder program if you want to chase both size and strength at the same time. My suggestions are purely bodybuilding centric because you said you wanted to get swole

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69694022
This is my upper/lower split:
Day 1: Upper
Bench press
Pullups
OHP
Barbell rows (might be iffy due to lower day after, substitute with whatever else horizontal pull)
Barbell curls partially superset with Skullcrushers

Day 2: Lower
Deadlift
Front squats
Leg press
Hanging leg raises

Day 3: Rest

Day 4: Upper 2
OHP
Pendlay row (same deal as other row)
Close grip bench
Pullups
Barbell curls partially superset with Skullcrushers

Day 5: Lower 2
Squat
RDL
Leg press
Hanging leg raises

Day 5-7: Rest, or another upper on day 6 only with high rep fluff stuff to hit what is neglected here (lateral delts, rear delts, some more arm volume etc).

So this is A/B. But how I actually tend to run it most of the time is to only do one variant for a couple of weeks for more specificity. Want to bench more? A variant only. OHP is garbage? B variant. Same for lower, except that DL'ing x2 a week gets iffy beyond a certain point.

Did "beginner" shrooms once, it was pretty fun, the ceiling changed colors depending on the music that played (fun music - brighter tones, sad music - darker tones), when I was lying down I actually felt how my legs stretched some 5meters/16feet, I managed to push the walls of the doorframe apart and I have felt pushing them. The girl who I was doing shrooms with was half asleep and lying on the bed, I lied next to her and pushed my face into her hair and I have felt every single hair grazing my face.
Did LSD for the first time (100micrograms/1 tab) in July, first I was a bit nervous as I didn't know what to expect, then I felt my body was five times heavier as I laid on the grass in shorts, but then it got easier I felt a constant relief. The clouds were shifting in a cool way, I looked at some photos of girls and they were moving, the ground was "breathing" as the sun rays evaporated the moisture and I've felt the waves of warm air exiting the soil and going along my body.
Up until now (6 months later) I experience more pleasure from listening to music (10-15% more pleasurable) and I perceive nature in a more "high definition" way, I get to "take in the whole picture" when looking at the sky/horizon more.
I haven't done big doses but I'd say mushrooms are more potent than LSD, but I'd suggest doing LSD.

posts.com:
I grew them in college. I actually mailed off to get spores from PF about 6 months before he got raided by the DEA. I only grew two batches because the penalties in my state for manufacture are insane and I didn’t trust my roommates not to tell their friends. My first trip was a heroic dose. I took 12 wet grams of pasture shrooms (before I grew them) and I ended up laying on my front porch balcony for hours trying to bite the concrete. I know how stupid that sounds but I just wanted to feel it between my teeth. Concrete on a balcony is flat, so I never succeeded in getting to bite it. At some point my sober roommates came home and asked me if I was ok. I said “no. I think I need to go to the hospital.” The asked me if I was serious and I realized I didn’t want it all to get that complicated so I said no, not knowing if I was going to survive. Spoiler: I survived.

The next time was when I had grown them. I took about 5 dry grams of PC and when they started to hit I drove over to my friends house because I was scared to be alone. He was watching the 6th sense when I got there so I had to sit in his couch watching that while tripping on 5 grams. I do not recommend anyone do that.

As I aged I did them a few times, but it had to be when my wife and kids were out of town. But I don’t grow them anymore so I got them from my almost-homeless family member. I've done shrooms well under a dozen times, first tried LSD at 18 and it was like shattering the reality hymen and falling out of the sky.
Shrooms are a bit more mellow depending on the dose and would strongly suggest you do them in a good mind state and an appropriate setting.
If you are a risk-taker and aspiring psychonaut who is willing to test the integrity of your psyche, I wouldn't recommend doing them in a public place. Even parks are subject to scrutiny and getting fucked with by outside elements like random passersby who don't know that you're tripping balls. And especially cops who will think you are some crazed half naked meth-head.

my best trip was at 19-20, in the middle of a redwood forest in Oregon in the winter with some really good friends. We tripped at a hot-springs over night and the trip was like shedding a tired soul and I felt clean and reborn and at peace with the world.
psychs are great and all but sometimes their effects are muddled in with other drugs. Like molly or speed or whatever.
they can be extremely powerful when used in the right settings.

but ultimately it's your actions or your practice in your daily waking life that will lead to long term effects of contentedness and discipline. shrooms and psychs just give you a peek at your unconscious or an overextended depth of senses.
